results.title: Mine on Channel Reef
results.creator_credit: Australia. Dept. of Defence and Vincent Donovan
results.brief_description: Two divers swimming near Channel Reef, a coral reef off the coast of Cairns in Queensland, come across a live mine. The Royal Australian Navy locate and dispose of the mine.

results.title: Mindscape
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Gaston Sarault and Jacques Drouin
results.brief_description: A particularly creative example of the pinscreen animation technique, this film is about an artist who steps inside his painting and wanders about in a landscape peopled with symbols that trigger unexpected associations. Film without words. (Eighteen awards including Ottawa; Yorkton; Columbus; New York; Los Angeles)

results.title: Mind your back
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, John Martin-Jones and Bruce Bennett
results.brief_description: The proper method of lifting heavy loads in coal mines. Demonstrates correct and incorrect methods in a variety of circumstrances, including raising, carrying and lowering a load; lifting, pushing and pulling a prop; lifting a gas cylinder, bag of cement, and 44 gallon drum; and team lifting.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, John Martin-Jones and Bruce Bennett

results.title: Mind of Tibet
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
In the late 1990s in Tibet a ceremonial Buddhist teaching festival was conducted. A monk was asked to take a VHS handycam through the crowd, documenting the event so that the undeniable existence of these devout people could be ‘captured’. The tape was to be an enormous family album for exiled Tibetans around the world. But it was also a witnessing document in case any misfortune befell the pilgrims. It was a subtle, pragmatic act of remembrance.

Years later, when Australian artist Sue Ford sat with eminent Buddhist scholar and teacher Geshe Sonam Thargye to view the tapes in Geelong, they felt it was extraordinarily clear that the camera had absorbed something more than a crowd at a festival. They realised that they had the makings of a meditative environment that could bear witness to the compassion that is the subject of so much Buddhist teaching. As they began to assemble the shots, they found that the sequencing of the ceremonies and teachings guided their editing decisions for the installation.

The video footage was composed of all-encompassing loops radiating around the viewer as the monk’s camera traced circle after circle through the crowd, and as the chants and ceremonies of nourishment enfolded the crowd in a compassionate assembly of learning and witnessing. To complete this concentric aesthetic, the artists suggested the array of eight screens as a way of immersing visitors within the crowd of pilgrims. Sitting within the circumambient mandala, visitors to the installation find themselves in the midst of a consciousness that knows how the past, present and future are all folded into each other, in the endlessly remembering ‘Mind of Tibet’.

Geshe Sonam Thargye is an eminent Tibetan lama serving with the Tibetan government in-exile based in Dharamsala, India. He also spends a significant portion of his time teaching in Geelong, Australia. Sue Ford was a Victorian filmmaker and one of Australia’s leading photographic portrait makers.

results.title: Mind-slaughter
results.brief_description: A look at the atmosphere of the earth and other planets as oceans of gases providing planetary life-support systems, and the consequences of an experiment to create an atmosphere for human habitation on another planet at the cost of existing life forms. Dramatically presented but fascinating comparative analysis, nonetheless, of earth and venus’s atmosphere - with a view to human habitation on the latter. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Mina Tannenbaum
results.creator_credit: Ima Films, LA SFFC, Christian Bourgois Productions, La Sept Cinema, FCC, Les Films de L'Etang, Georges Benayoun and Martine Dugowson
results.brief_description: This debut from director Martine Dugowson is a poignant study of friendship as it stands the test of time. Two French Jewish girls - Ethel and Mina, are begrudgingly thrown together by their mutual lack of ascribing to social conventions in Paris in the late 1960’s. As they move into adolescence their friendship blossoms, becomes the only source of happiness, and sometimes a source of conflict as they move away from their peer groups and family. The film chronicles 25 years of the lives and loves of two best friends who share a love/hate relationship. Cast includes Romane Bohringer, Elsa Zylberstein, Florence Thomassin and Nils Tavernier. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Mimi: an evening with Aboriginal Islander Dance Theatre
results.creator_credit: Reese/Smith Productions, Smith Productions, Andee Reese and Margaret Anne Smith
results.brief_description: Students from the Aboriginal Islander Dance Theatre perform several of their dance pieces which demonstrate their ability to perform modern dance as well as more traditional dance forms, with, at times, an innovative blending of the two.

results.title: Mimi pulka (A)
results.creator_credit: Voice Productions, SBS-TV, Ruth Carr and Catherine Adams
results.brief_description: In an effort to break down existing myths about HIV/AIDS and present the information in a way that was culturally appropriate for Aborigines, the Kimberley Aboriginal Medical Service in Broome commissioned a play entitled “No prejudice” and sent it on tour throughout the Kimberley region. This video follows the touring company of five actors and advisers and highlights the importance of why alternatives to the written word are necessary to a people whose culture is essentially oral.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Voice Productions, SBS-TV, Ruth Carr and Catherine Adams

results.title: Mime over matter
results.creator_credit: Sim Productions, Kratky Film, Morton Schindel and Gene Deitch
results.brief_description: Examines the use of pantomime to explore ideas and provoke open-ended discussion of such topics as man’s relationship to the material objects that make his life comfortable. Features Ladislav Fialka and his Prague Pantomime.

results.title: MIMA Yearbook. Vol. 3
results.brief_description: Volume three of a three volume set, this video compilation of excerpts of Australian film and video art covers the period from 1983-1986, and is a unique and tantalising entry into the non-mainstream history of Australian film and video.
